title: Paul’s First Missionary Journey
shortSummary: Acts 13 details the commissioning of Paul and Barnabas by the Holy Spirit for missionary work, their journey to Cyprus and Pisidia, and Paul’s powerful sermon in the synagogue at Antioch. This chapter marks a pivotal moment in the spread of the gospel to the Gentiles and highlights the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy in Jesus Christ.
timeline: c. AD 46-48 - Beginning of Paul’s First Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: A prominent early Christian and companion of Paul, known for his encouragement and leadership in the Antioch church.

keyCharacters.name: Saul (Paul)
keyCharacters.description: Also called Paul, a former persecutor of the church who becomes a leading apostle and missionary spreading the gospel to the Gentiles.

keyCharacters.name: John Mark
keyCharacters.description: Servant and assistant to Paul and Barnabas on this journey, who later becomes an important figure in the early church.

keyCharacters.name: Elymas (Barjesus)
keyCharacters.description: A Jewish sorcerer and false prophet who opposes Paul and Barnabas, and is struck blind by Paul’s Spirit-empowered rebuke.

keyCharacters.name: Sergius Paulus
keyCharacters.description: The Roman deputy (proconsul) of Cyprus who, after witnessing God’s power, believes the gospel preached by Paul.

definitions.definition: The third Person of the Trinity, who empowers, guides, and directs believers in their service to God.
A spiritual discipline involving abstaining from food or drink to seek God’s guidance and favor.
A Jewish place of worship and teaching where Paul often preached the gospel.
Declared righteous before God, a key doctrine showing that faith in Christ frees believers from the condemnation of the law.
Spiritual leaders in the early church gifted to proclaim God’s word and instruct the believers.

outline.heading: The Antioch Church and the Calling of Paul and Barnabas
outline.description: The Holy Spirit directs the church at Antioch to set apart Barnabas and Saul for missionary work, emphasizing prayer, fasting, and spiritual commissioning.

outline.heading: Missionary Journey Begins: Cyprus and Salamis
outline.description: Paul and Barnabas travel to Cyprus, preach in synagogues, confront the sorcerer Elymas, and witness the conversion of Sergius Paulus, demonstrating God’s power over falsehood.

outline.heading: Preaching in Pisidian Antioch
outline.description: Paul delivers a comprehensive sermon recounting Israel’s history and presenting Jesus as the promised Savior, calling people to repentance and faith in Him.

outline.heading: Response to the Gospel and Opposition
outline.description: Gentiles eagerly receive the message, while many Jews reject it and oppose Paul and Barnabas, leading to persecution and their departure to continue preaching elsewhere.

application: Seek God’s guidance through prayer and fasting when making important decisions or embarking on ministry.
Be bold in proclaiming the gospel, even in the face of opposition or rejection.
Recognize that God’s promises are fulfilled in Jesus Christ and share this truth clearly with others.
Rejoice and remain filled with the Holy Spirit despite trials and persecution.

keyVerses.text: As they ministered to the Lord, and fasted, the Holy Ghost said, Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the divine calling and commissioning of Paul and Barnabas for missionary service.

keyVerses.text: Be it known unto you therefore, men and brethren, that through this man is preached unto you the forgiveness of sins: And by him all that believe are justified from all things, from which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses.
keyVerses.significance: These verses clearly present the gospel message of forgiveness and justification through faith in Jesus Christ.

keyVerses.text: For so hath the Lord commanded us, saying, I have set thee to be a light of the Gentiles, that thou shouldest be for salvation unto the ends of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the mission to bring salvation to the Gentiles, expanding God’s covenant promises beyond Israel.

keyVerses.text: And the disciples were filled with joy, and with the Holy Ghost.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the joy and empowerment that comes from the Holy Spirit, even amid persecution.
